snippet: What happened to the newspaper and magazine business is about to happen to higher education: a rescrambling around the Web and online learning.
abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column observes that elite, pace-setting universities are now embracing the Internet and offering online courses; examines some of the concerns that experts have expressed about the trend; asserts that although the concerns are legitimate, online learning has the potential to allow the most committed schools and students to be better than ever. (M)
lead_paragraph: Online education is not new. The University of Phoenix started its online degree program in 1989. Four million college students took at least one online class during the fall of 2007. But, over the past few months, something has changed. The elite, pace-setting universities have embraced the Internet. Not long ago, online courses were interesting experiments. Now online activity is at the core of how these schools envision their futures.
